title: 106_hr876
content: Increase in contribution limits and phase-out amounts for individual retirement account contributions. The maximum amount of contribution to Individual Retirement Accounts is increased, with the applicable amount being $2,500 for taxable years beginning in 1999 and a different amount for years after 1999 and before 2008. The maximum contribution to Individual Retirement Accounts is increased to $7,000 for taxable years beginning after 2007, with an inflation adjustment for years after 2008. The maximum contribution to Individual Retirement Accounts is increased to $7,000 for taxable years beginning after 2007, with an inflation adjustment for years after 2008. Any adjusted amounts not multiples of $10 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Amendments are made to the limitation on deduction for active participants in certain pension plans for taxable years beginning in 1999 and after. For taxable years beginning after 2003, the applicable dollar amount is $110,000. For other taxpayers, the amount varies based on the year, with adjustments made annually. For taxable years beginning after 2003, the applicable dollar amount is $110,000, which is subject to inflation adjustments. For taxable years beginning after 2003, the applicable dollar amount is $110,000, subject to inflation adjustments. Section 1(f)(3) adjusts amounts for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, rounding to the nearest multiple of $100. Conforming amendments update the applicable amounts under sections 408(a) and 408(b)(2) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998, adjusting dollar amounts in various sections of the Code. Penalty-free distributions are allowed under this section, applicable to taxable years starting after December 31, 1998, with adjustments to dollar amounts in the Code. Penalty-free distributions for first homes and higher education extended to certain plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments made to subparagraphs (E) and (F) of section 72(t)(2) allow penalty-free distributions from employer contributions. Additionally, penalty-free distributions for certain unemployed individuals are not limited to health insurance costs and allowed from 401(k) plans. (c) Unlimited Penalty-Free Distributions for Medical Care and Expanded Definition of Dependents for Purposes of Such Distributions.-- Subparagraph (B) of section 72(t)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow penalty-free distributions for medical care without limitations on dependents. Penalty-free distributions for medical care from individual retirement plans or employer contributions are allowed without regard to itemized deductions or exceeding 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income. Dependents for such distributions include all children. The amendments made by this section apply to payments and distributions in taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998, with dependents defined as including all children, grandchildren, and ancestors of the individual or their spouse.
